ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A greater understanding of integrals and derivatives and an intuition for 3d geometry.
I learned about the basic concepts of multivariable calculus, including derivatives, integrals, vectors, and various theorems. I also learned techniques to identify in what cases to use what methods.
Multivariable calculus
Calculus 3 skills
3D stuff. Most important... hw to be in a community( the OH community  was great)

Having already taken multivariable calculus in high school, I can definitely say this course offered me a much greater insight into the conceptual basis for much of the theorems and methods used in the course. I was not taught to just use a theorem as fact but was taught why the theorem worked and physical interpretations of the theorem.
A deeper understanding of functions of multiple variables and how they behave, as well as an improvement in my skills in mathematical analysis and problem-solving
Visualizing figures in 3D, calculations, etc
All the important theorems and skills needed to do multivariable calculus. Learned how some of the principles had important real world applications.
I definitely expanded and solidified my knowledge of multi variable calculus. I also realized that I do enjoy learning math.
Multivariable calculus
I feel very comfortable with multivariable calculus and I am excited to use what I learned in future classes.
I learned how to apply principles of calculus to a greater level of dimensions (i.e., 3-dimensional spaces).
I learned multivariable calculus
Understanding of multivariable calc
Multi variable calculus.
I learned multivariable calculus concepts from a relatively conceptual/theory-based perspective.
Ability to organize a great quantity of skills and information in my head.

I developed new knowledge of various topics in multivariable calculus (triple integrals, double integrals, plane and line equations, etc.), learning the relevant theory and formulas, techniques to solve problems, and gaining practice with various example problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Pablo is a great teacher who explained concepts extremely well.  Furthermore, the small class sizes allowed us to do practice problems in class, which was very engaging and helped facilitate learning.

Weaknesses: the required textbook readings, required videos, and then class lectures covered a lot of the same materials, and it got a repetetive.  I found that skipping the required videos saved time without detracting from my knowledge, and I guess this weakness doesn't matter since no one checks whether you've done the readings/videos.

Weakness: There is not enough of an effort made to teach students how to have an intuition for the theorems.
Strength: Strong support framework

The subject matter was organized in a logical fashion (i.e subsequent lessons built upon previous ones). The small class size facilitates students working together and asking questions more actively. The additional resources given, including the peer tutor office hours and Ximera, are pretty helpful at guiding people towards the right process and answers (the pre-class quizzes didn't offer much value, since they could be completed without watching the video and vice versa). However, the overall course was organized in a way that showed a considerable lack of consideration for students' schedules: whereas other courses would not have a pset due on the week of a midterm/final so that students can focus on preparing, this class would assign an additional pset with an earlier due date. The workload and pace of the course is not impossible to keep up with (and the material itself is not too difficult, if perhaps initially confusing) but does cause more stress than is necessary. The quality of feedback is inconsistent: at times, TAs would indicate that there was a certain type of mistake, but stop short of specifying how it should be corrected.
I dont think there's much more to improve - it's already a clearly organized and set course.
I wish we were explained concepts for in depth within this class
The review sessions at the beginning were hosted on Wednesday and Thursday( most people can't  make it because the assignment is due on Thursday so people are at OH)

I enjoy the idea of having both the lectures and the videos but sometimes I found it extremely cumbersome, especially during busy weeks. Prof. Boixeda Alvarez did a good job of making sure to teach as if students had not watched the videos at the beginning to ensure every student was on the same page. The small class size was also a big strength. One weakness I would say is that the instructors dont release information in advance for exam review sessions
I like how we are introduced to concepts remotely first and then go over them in-person. This reinforcement of knowledge makes concepts easier to remember.
Strengths was it was very organized but cons was it moved very fast, leaving students behind.

I thought the course was very well taught. My professor (Prof. Alvarez) did a very good job at explaining things and answering questions from students about ideas that were less intuitive. He also allowed plenty of time to work practice problems and assisted students during class. I didnt think there were any weaknesses.
I think the course was fine as is.

Lots of available office hours for doing homework and asking questions. Weakness is mainly how some of the homework was more focused on computational skills that arent really assessed on the exams instead of main concepts

I think that the strengths of this course are that it is very well organized, and there were always practice exams which were very helpful for studying. I do not have any suggestions as my experience was fantastic in this class.
This course was paced very well, and the assignments made it easy to quickly and solidly learn the concepts.
Pretty good overall
Smaller class sizes
Well structured course
Ximeras
While I did not particularly enjoy or excel in the course material, this course benefits from a useful and helpful network of peer tutor support and office hours.
I think sometime this class could be made more interesting, but it was taught very clearly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  This course is very fun (if you like math/calculus) and was taught in a great way.
Yes if your major requires math.

I'd only recommend this course to someone who needs it for prereqs or major requirements if you can't find an alternative to satisfy them. It's probably marginally more useful computation-wise if you're doing physics, since vectors do come up quite a bit.
Yes, it teaches you materials that are necessary to a lot of fields including engineering and economics.
No because I did not like that a bulk of the learning was done through videos

No, its too much work for little reward... those psets took me 10hrs or more a week with the OH I had to attend and they was only 10% contribution toward my grade. Maybe I was just bad at taking exams ( but exam grades were never representative  of how much work I had to put into this class, which left me always frustrated and stressed).

Math120 is not as bad as people say it is. Youll have to put in a bit of work, sure, but the class isnt impossible and as long as you go to office hours youll be able to get this course done with an A or A- easily. I would only recommend this course if its necessary for the major, though.
Yes, it's a straight-forward core math class for many majors
Yes. It is a good course to build mathematical intuition in calculus 3
Yes, the course is essential if someone is looking to go further in math. It is also very well taught and not too difficult.
Yes. If the student is interested in math, Multivariable is essential and this course definitely solidified that skill area.
Yes, if you need it for major requirements
I would definitely recommend this course, the teaching was great and it is applicable to many stem fields.
Yes. Mathematical concepts learned in this course will help you for future STEM courses.
Yes, it was a great way to learn multi from the ground up
I would if they are dedicated to math
Yes

I would recommend this course to another student. I believe most students in STEM majors are supposed to take this course as a prerequisite, and it does help with understanding more advanced calculus.
I would, but only if you really enjoy math. If you dont, it could be more difficult.

I would recommend this course for students interested in pursuing more calculus, as it teaches a wide variety of topics that are useful for higher level math and other related subjects. The course had outlets for academic support outside of class and office hours, like peer tutoring and review sessions prior to exams.
